message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pyloric stenosis. The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. Barium upper GI series is not recommended as the first-line test due to the risk of aspiration. Air enema is not appropriate in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant suggest infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test for IHPS is abdominal ultrasound, which will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. Barium upper GI series may also be used, but it is not the first-line diagnostic test for IHPS. The bird beak sign and corkscrewing are findings associated with achalasia, not IHPS. Air enema is used to treat intussusception, which is not the likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the palpable mass suggest pyloric stenosis. Abdominal ultrasound is the first-line diagnostic test for pyloric stenosis, which will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. Barium upper GI series and air enema are not recommended for infants with suspected pyloric stenosis because of the risk of aspiration and bowel perforation. Barium upper GI series is used to diagnose esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula with the bird beak sign and corkscrewing. Air enema is used to diagnose intussusception with the filling defect and coil spring sign.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical picture of projectile vomiting, palpable mass in the right upper quadrant, and normal developmental milestones is consistent with pyloric stenosis. The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. The other options are not appropriate for diagnosing pyloric stenosis. Option A is associated with esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula. Option B is associated with achalasia. Option C is associated with intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s symptoms, including violent vomiting and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant, suggest pyloric stenosis. Abdominal ultrasound is the first-line confirmatory diagnostic test for pyloric stenosis, and it will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. Barium upper GI series can also be used but will show a bird beak sign and corkscrewing. Air enema can diagnose intussusception, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of "violent vomiting" starting about 3 days ago and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant suggests the most likely diagnosis is pyloric stenosis. The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test would be an abdominal ultrasound which would show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. A barium upper GI series or air enema can also be used for diagnosis, but ultrasound is the preferred method in infants. The other options are not associated with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including violent vomiting and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant, suggest pyloric stenosis. The first-line confirmatory test is an abdominal ultrasound, which would show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. Barium upper GI series and air enema are also options for confirmation, but abdominal ultrasound is the first-line choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of projectile vomiting, weight gain, and a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant suggests pyloric stenosis, which can be confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound. The diagnostic finding will be an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. The other options are incorrect as they are associated with other conditions. Barium upper GI series is used to diagnose achalasia and esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula while air enema is used to diagnose intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest an obstructive lesion in the gastrointestinal tract, and pyloric stenosis is the most likely diagnosis. The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test for pyloric stenosis is an abdominal ultrasound, which typically reveals an elongated pyloric channel and hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle. Barium upper GI series and air enema are not recommended because they may increase the risk of perforation in infants with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of violent vomiting and palpable mass suggest hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The first-line confirmatory diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which will show an elongated pyloric channel and muscle hypertrophy. The other options are associated with different diagnoses such as hiatal hernia or intestinal obstruction.
